entry.title: SAP Community Team Spotlight: Josh Bentley - September 2025 Edition
entry.content:
You probably have already seen the past interviews of this series (one / two / three / four / five / six / seven / eight ) which were done by my colleague Marco Santos. Today I am very excited to introduce you to another amazing person behind the SAP Community platform. Here we are with another SAP Community Spotlight, @josh_bentley ! 

 

Fatemeh Zarei (FZ): Hi Josh! Thank you so much for joining us today. To kick things off - would you like to tell us a little bit about your iconic blue beard? How did that all start?

Josh Bentley: So, every superhero has their own origin story - mine's just a little less dramatic. Iâ€™ve been talking about technology for nearly 25 years, and in 2018, I joined the Developer Advocates team after leaving the Cloud Center of Excellence. At a conference - SAP TechEd - the women on our team had all these vibrant hair colors and teased us guys for being boring. I thought, â€œWhy is it only the women showing personality?â€ But I donâ€™t have hair - Iâ€™m bald! So, one of them said, â€œWell, you can dye your beard.â€ I didnâ€™t take it seriously at first, but before SAP TechEd in 2019, I thought, "Why not?" I texted her for tips, used paper towels to mix colors until I got close to SAP blue, and Iâ€™ve kept it ever since. This October marks six years! What keeps me doing it is not just for my ego boost but for the smiles I get from others and the joy they truly show me when they see me.

FZ: Thatâ€™s fantastic! Now, shifting gears a bit - how did you first get involved with the SAP Community?

Josh: That goes back to my pre-sales days, around 2011 or 2012, when we had the â€œBlog It Forwardâ€ campaign that Moshe Naveh started. I was a solution engineer at the time and joined in by answering the campaign questions, then tagging others. That was my first real blog post and entry into the community. I wasnâ€™t one of the founders or key players at the start - it was more of a resource to find answers or share thoughts. But thatâ€™s where it began for me.

FZ: What's your current role on the SAP Community team, and what does a typical day look like?

Josh: These days, I focus on promoting community advocacy. I help highlight whatâ€™s working and where we can improve. My work is all about connecting with people - online and in person - and making sure their voices are heard. Thereâ€™s no â€œtypicalâ€ day, but it involves a mix of content creation, listening to feedback, and strategizing how to make the community better.

FZ: Youâ€™ve done so much! Whatâ€™s one part of the SAP community experience that youâ€™re particularly proud of?

Josh: Itâ€™s hard to pick one, but Iâ€™ll mention three chapters in my SAP life. First, I was part of the team that transitioned SAP from BlackBerry to Apple devices, which was a major enterprise shift. We tackled security, analytics access, BYOD - it was a huge cross-functional effort. Then in pre-sales, I traveled extensively and gave technical demos to some of the biggest companies in the world. I got comfortable and confident in front of customers because I prepared so thoroughly - â€œsharpening the axe,â€ as they say. And in the Developer Advocate role, one big highlight was being trusted to go on stage for SAP TechEd, even during the COVID era when we broadcasted from Frankfurt. Being able to be myself and present on a global stage was unforgettable.

FZ: Amazing. Do you have a favorite or most memorable moment in the community?

Josh: One standout was my first SAP TechEd in Barcelona. Being in a role where I get to visit an amazing city like that is something else, but the real magic was seeing the show floor and the scale of how many SAP mentors and other legacy members made the trip. Some of my first SAP selfies with people I would work with for years were taken at that event.

FZ: How do you stay in tune with the communityâ€™s needs and feedback?

Josh: Three main ways. First, in-person events. Thatâ€™s where people are really open. Online, they might not comment or engage as much, but in person theyâ€™ll say, â€œHey, I saw your video!â€ Second, I post on YouTube and LinkedIn to keep communication flowing. Third, I look at outside platforms like Reddit or Stack Overflow to see what SAP techies are saying in the wild.

FZ: If you could wave a magic wand and change one thing in the community, what would it be?

Josh: Iâ€™d love to see more people offering constructive feedback - with solutions in mind. Not just â€œthis is broken,â€ but â€œhereâ€™s how it could be better.â€ I know we canâ€™t always implement every suggestion - due to technology limitations or staffing - but the community is stronger when members help shape it. The community is bigger than just a website. Itâ€™s every conversation, every event. And we need our members to be co-owners in it.

FZ: And one final question - do you have any advice for those new to SAP or the SAP Community, like me?

Josh: Absolutely. Be your own advocate. No one else is going to push you harder than you will. Learn how your managers listen. In meetings - listen first. Figure out how you can add value. People ask how they can have a role like mine. I say, there are two ways: either start a company and create your own path - or gain experience over time. I didnâ€™t go to school for SAP. I started wiring buildings, setting up IT systems, and just kept learning. Over time, I built a brand and a reputation for being honest, responsive, and knowledgeable. Have a point of view - or put in the work. Thereâ€™s no shortcut. Just engage with kindness and curiosity, and the rest will come.

FZ:  What a wonderful way to wrap things up! Thank you so much, Josh, for joining me today and sharing your SAP journey with us. Itâ€™s been a real pleasure having you here.

Josh: Thanks, Fatemeh. I really enjoyed our conversation.

entry.title: ğŸŒŸ Welcome to the SAP Community Group Nigeria! ğŸŒŸ
entry.content:
Hello SAP Nigeria Enthusiasts! ğŸ‘‹

Weâ€™re super excited to kick off the SAP Community Group in Nigeria, a space created for collaboration, learning, and innovation within our local SAP ecosystem. Whether youâ€™re a seasoned SAP professional, just starting out, or a business leader using SAP solutions to make an impact, this community is for you. Together, weâ€™ll share ideas, learn from each other, and build strong connections that grow the SAP network across Nigeria.

Our vision is to create a vibrant and dynamic community that thrives on collaboration and continuous learning. By sharing your knowledge, engaging in discussions, and supporting one another, we can build a strong SAP ecosystem that not only empowers professionals in Nigeria but also contributes to the global SAP family.

Why join the SAP Community Nigeria Group?
Hereâ€™s what you can look forward to:
ğŸ”¹Local Meetups & Events â€“ From informal gatherings to SAP-focused workshops and knowledge sessions, weâ€™ll create opportunities to connect in person.
ğŸ”¹Knowledge Sharing â€“ Publish blogs, ask questions, and share insights on SAP solutions and innovations. Your contributions form the backbone of this community.
ğŸ”¹Networking & Growth â€“ Build relationships with SAP experts, professionals, and enthusiasts across Nigeria and beyond.
ğŸ”¹Celebrate Success Stories â€“ Share how SAP is driving transformation in your career, business, or industryâ€”we want to spotlight local heroes.
How you can get involved

ğŸ‘‰ Join the Group  
ğŸ‘‰Post your Introduction  (tell us about your SAP journey, location, and interests)

ğŸ‘‰Stay tuned for events and discussions that bring learning and collaboration to life
Letâ€™s Build the Future â€“ Together
This community will only be as strong as the people in it. By sharing your knowledge, engaging in discussions, and supporting others, youâ€™ll help us build a vibrant SAP ecosystem in Nigeria.

ğŸš€Together, letâ€™s make the SAP Community Nigeria a hub of innovation, collaboration, and growth!

About the Initiator 

Charles Nwankwo is an SAP PP/QM Consultant with over six years of professional experience. His career has spanned multiple industries, including manufacturing, consumer goods, beverages, pharmaceuticals, and chemicals. He has contributed to several end-to-end SAP projects, ranging from Greenfield and Brownfield S/4HANA implementations to public cloud deployments. Beyond technical expertise, these experiences have deepened his understanding of the challenges and opportunities that organizations face during SAP transformation.

Driven by a passion for collaboration, he established this community to create a platform where SAP professionals in Nigeria can connect, exchange insights, and collectively drive innovation.

@lauraschmitz #SAP#SAPCommunityNigeria

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: Mind Your Step (Walking and Hiking)
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm Moshe Naveh from the SAP Community team. Today, I'm excited to kick off a new SAP Community virtual journey: a blogging series focused on the passions and hobbies of our community members. In this series, community members will share about themselves, their hobbies, how they got started, how they incorporate them into their routine, and how you can learn them as well. This series will be enriched with fun stories, inspiring anecdotes, images, videos, and more. Each community member will tag another member to join the series via their mutual interest. For now we've lined up community members with the following hobbies: painting, Mindfulness, Yoga, skydiving, running, and more! 

I want to start the series by sharing a hobby that has been my passion for a long time: long walks and hiking. It all started when I did my first step, around the age of eighteen monthsğŸ˜‰. However, when I was a teenager I started taking long walks. I used to love to walk on the beach just before the sun switched turns with the moon. There was a sculpture of a bird that always inspired and reminded me that I'm free to go wherever I want. 

The title of this blog post, "Mind Your Step," reflects my state of mind when I walk. I try to be mindful of every step I make. Each step not only brings you closer to the finish line but also can take you deeper into your own thoughts and relaxation. 

Now, I would like to share with you some pictures from my most significant hikes and walks that really are a part of who I'm today:

Bolivian Jungle

Around 2004, I went on a long hike in the jungles of Bolivia (a couple of hours drive from La Paz). It was an amazing experience where I met new people and formed meaningful connections. For a couple of days we walked through jungles, slept in remote areas, and relied on each other's trust to navigate the unknown. 

Isla Grande, Brazil

Another memorable hike from around 2004 was my visit to Isla Grande which is an island not far away from Rio De Janeiro. After settling down in the camping ground, I met two cool people which later became my friends. Shortly afterwards we decided to do a hike of 40 km to cross the island from bottom to top. I was the man of the day as I saved everyone by bringing "just in case" food in my bag. My friends thought we would find food in the middle of the jungle:). They returned a favor by searching for me when I got lost in the jungle (they found meğŸ˜‰). We finished our hike when we reached the tip of the island. The traditional dish of rice and beans was so tasty. For sure it was refreshing after eating Tuna, cookies and Goose liver Pate for five days.  The timing of arrival to the finish line was perfect as we got there just in time for the weekly ferry to the main village.

Luxembourg's Little Switzerland

Three years ago, I did the longest walk I've ever done in one day (30 Km). It was in the magnificent area of Luxembourg called "Little Switzerland." The trail resembled Switzerland's mountains and had stunning views. The focus wasn't just the amazing nature and yummy blackberries but also my state of mind during the hike. It was with certainty one of my most special days in my entire life:

That's how I look when I finish a 30 KM hike 

And it was such an amazing view:

I'm standing on a bridge over a swamp

 

and here are the tasty blackberries:

 

25 km walk

During my recent holiday, I decided to dedicate one day for a long walk. I walked on the beach or not far away from it for 7-8 hours. I tried to walk always in the shade of buildings as it was very hot. I constantly bought food, snacks, and drinks (which seems to be my favorite part of the walkğŸ˜‰). 

This is how I looked after finishing the journey:

Moshe standing next to a tree after finishing 25 KM by foot

 

Running!

Recently, I started practicing for a race so I started running. Although I was already in shape from walking 15â€“20 km daily, running gave me a whole new feeling of energy:

After my first 12 KM run!

  and I really enjoy stopping in my favorite street and eating all sorts of fruits that are available for everyone:

Grapes

Recently I started to be interested in races. Here's a picture from a race that was raising funds for children with cancer:                                                                   

Moshe in a running race

Subscribe to this post as I'll add in the comments pictures from the upcoming race, after I complete it:).

Why did I start walking and running?

I really enjoy walking as it calms me down, excite me and keeps me in shape. It's a kind of meditation for me. Running is also very relaxing but at a different pace than walking. I hope I'll keep doing both for a long time, while doing it right to maintain a healthy body. Also starting a day with a morning run keeps you energized at least until lunch:).

Passing the baton:

Now, I'd like to hand it over to Achim ( @act45 ). Achim has been a community member for many years and I'm sure many of you know him. I was fortunate to meet Achim in person in SAP TechEd. Achim will share his amazing experiences and journey around being a yoga teacher and a Mindfulness enthusiastic. As I practice Mindfulness during my runs and walks, I think it's a great continuation for our blogging series.

Do you do long walks or hike? Share the pictures and stories behind them in the comments section. Feel free to share other hobbies you have! 

If you're interested in joining the series, please reach out to me via community@sap.com.

Let's get this journey going! I hope you all enjoy the great posts coming-up!

entry.title: Devtoberfest 2025 - Integration track sessions
entry.content:
We are days away from the first session of this year's Devtoberfest, our annual virtual celebration dedicated to the SAP developer community. Like previous years, there is a lot going on in the integration space, and as part of Devtoberfest 2025 we will have sessions covering the following topics: Architecture, AI, Event-driven Architectures, Tools for integration developers, open source and more.

As you might be aware, every track is assigned a unique day across the four weeks that Devtoberfest takes place and Wednesdays will be all about integration.

Devtoberfest 2025 sessions

You can find all the different tracks/sessions that are part of Devtoberfest here. You can filter all events by selecting the topic (label) you are interested in, e.g. integration ğŸ˜‰.

Let me quickly share all the sessions that we will have as part of the integration track:

1st of October:

  • 09:30 - ğŸ”´Pipeline for Cloud Integration
  • 11:00 - ğŸ”´ Clean Core, Event-Driven: Unlocking SAP Value with Advanced Event Mesh
  • 13:00 - ğŸ”´ Designing understandable SAP BTP Solution Diagrams and contributing to the SAP Architecture Center
  • 15:00 - ğŸ”´ IT System Landscape Transparency with Open Resource Discovery (ORD)

8th of October:

  • 09:30 - ğŸ”´ Warp-Speed for Event Creation: Overview on the new Event Add-on for ERP
  • 11:00 - ğŸ”´ Hands-on session: practical demonstration of the Event Add-on for ERP
  • 13:30 - ğŸ”´ Enterprise in Motion: Event-Driven Architecture Use Cases for Innovation and Agility
  • 17:00 - ğŸ”´ Unleash Next-Generation Hybrid Integration with Edge Integration Cell

15th of October:

  • 09:30 - ğŸ”´ Using Intermediate Message Events and Success Factors Events in SAP Build Process Automation
  • 11:00 - ğŸ”´ Seamless side-by-side extensibility with SAP Build and SAP Cloud Application Event Hub
  • 13:30 - ğŸ”´SAP Cloud ALM - Integration & Exception Monitoring in Context for SAP Integration Suite (Cloud Integration)
  • 15:00 - ğŸ”´ Partner Directory Accelerator Tool for Pipeline Concept - an SAP open-source project

22th of October:

  • 09:30 - ğŸ”´ AI for Integration Excellence: Modernize, Optimize, Thrive
  • 11:00 - ğŸ”´ Future-proof your scripts in SAP Cloud Integration
  • 13:30 - ğŸ”´ A(P)I: Unified connectivity for AI applications using MCP

Note: If you click on any of the times of the sessions above, you will download the calendar invite for the session.

So go ahead and RSVP to the different sessions you are interested in. Also, make sure to download the calendar invites so that you don't miss the session and you can get a chance to ask the speaker any questions that you might have about the topic.

Happy learning this Devtoberfest 2025!

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: Exciting Blog Posts, Countdown for Devtoberfest, and More!
entry.content:
One of the best things about September so far is how our platform has many new improvements, active members, features for developers, location groups, and events. There are many reasons to explore and engage inside SAP Community, but this is the type of month that makes everyone feel more excited to learn, connect, and dive deeply into all topics related to SAP.

This SAP Community Voice newsletter highlights some of these updates, summarizes trending topics, explores details about Devtoberfest, and spotlights opportunities to participate in upcoming virtual and physical events, including SAP TechEd.

Read more below to find out whatâ€™s happening in and around SAP Community!

Featured Content

SAP ILM Store Configuration with Microsoft Azure Storage

If you are looking for organized and clear steps on how to configure SAP ILM store with Microsoft Azure Blob, we recommend this content written by @Rahul_Das65. This technical guide covers the prerequisites, authorizations required, certificates, and instructions for testing the connection in the end. To make your life easier, he made sure to include all the sources and useful documents as well.

Read the blog post

AI Agent â€“ First Release of the SAP Fiori MCP Server

This SAP Fiori MCP (Model Context Protocol) server marks a milestone in SAPâ€™s AI journey by introducing open-source tools for AI coding assistants that you create. In this post, @Christoph_Gollmick explains how MCP helps with large language models (LLMs) to ensure the most reliable results, while also supporting all developers by providing a faster and efficient experience when generating and adapting applications.

Read the blog post

Lessons on SAP Datasphere Architecture

Thinking about building a data solution with SAP Datasphere? This blog post by @haungo can be very helpful. He walks through the steps -- from an initial design to a final, more robust architecture. â€œLessons learnedâ€ content is always valuable because it provides the insights from the ups and downs of real-world projects.

Read the blog post

New GenAI Feature Available for SAP Integration Suite Version 6.69

SAPÂ´s @DeepakGDeshpande shares details about the new Generative AI based Integration Flow Generation with Mediations Steps feature that boosts the efficiency of the development process. The feature is currently available for the premium edition in specific regions/data centers, but SAP will add more as the rollout of the software feature continues.

Read the blog post

Community News

More Kudos, More Badges

If youâ€™re an active member who supports other members by giving them kudos, we are now acknowledging your engagement efforts with a new badge progression set. Youâ€™ll earn the first badge in the set with your very first kudo, then receive more badges after giving 30 kudos, then 75, 200, and 500 as the final milestone. Check more details in this Whatâ€™s New post, which provides a full overview about how this simple act makes such a big impact for our community.

New Design Pilot: We Still Need Your Feedback

In our last edition of SAP Community Voice, we mentioned how we were running a pilot to test a new layout for blog posts that removes widgets and white spaces from the right column, as a way to make the reading experience better. This feature will be available until September 23, so that means another week for you to give us your opinion! You can read more about the pilot in this post and share your feedback in the comments.

New Location Group in Africa

We are so happy that our Middle East and Africa location groups are growing this year. This month we would like to welcome our new Nigeria group, curated by @CharledNwankwo, who has been an active member since 2020. Check now his first blog post on the group here. If you also live in this area, make sure to register to learn and connect with other members from your region and to support future physical events across Nigeria.

Josh Bentley Is Our SAP Community Team Spotlight for September 2025

Our SAP Community team spotlight series features interviews with the SAP colleagues dedicated to our community platform and our members, online and in-person. This month, we are super happy to highlight @josh_bentley (maybe you know him as Josh â€œBlueBeardâ€). In his interview with @fatemehzarei_001, Josh gives the details behind the idea of his iconic colorful beard, explains how he got involved with SAP Community, talks about his current role, and offers advice for those new to SAP and the community. Read the full interview and look for other interviews in the series, spotlighting Anne Kathrine Petteroe, Moshe Naveh, and Laura Schmitz,

New SAP Community Hobbies Series!

Last week, SAP's @moshenaveh launched a new blog series designed to shine a light on the hobbies and passions of community members. The main goal is to encourage you to share a bit about yourself. What topics bring you joy, keep you motivated, and help you balance your life? Participation in this series is a great way to connect with and inspire other members. Starting the series with this post, Moshe highlights walking and hiking, and we want to encourage you to read it and learn more about his adventures. If you have a cool hobby, please join the series and share your story with the community. We would love to hear about it!

Upcoming Events

The Countdown Is On: Two Weeks to Devtoberfest 2025

Is everyone ready for the most expected tech virtual festival? Because Devtoberfest is right around the corner to kick off the big SAP TechEd season! Starting on September 29, this free and online event will be full of sessions and activities, covering different topics such as ABAP, fronted tooling, AI innovations, and CAP. Beyond the educational content, the participants can play around with the fun activities prepared for Devtoberfest (and do not require you to show up at a specific time, allowing you more flexibility to take part in everything). Oh, and letÂ´s not forget that the competition is on, and you should definitely check out all the rules and prizes for the Devtoberfest 2025 Contest.

SAP TechEd Agenda Builder

For all our members who are planning to attend SAP TechEd 2025 in Berlin next month and need help to plan on what are the best options to participate (we know it is hard to choose with more than 250 different great sessions), we highly recommend the online agenda builder. This tool allows you to browse through all the sessions available, including keynotes, workshops, roadmaps, and much more. It is very simple to add the ones you are interested in attending to your dashboard and have a clear and clean view. This feature is also available for those participating in SAP TechEd Virtual, so you can plan your schedule whether you're joining in person or online.

SAP Inside Track Around the World

In our last SAP Community Voice newsletter, we highlighted that it's now easier to find local events using the new filter "Countryâ€. This new feature helps you discover events not directly linked to a location group (e.g., Portugal and Mexico meet-ups can be found even if not represented by a group), as well as events in these groups. Perhaps, if you explore the list, you will see how many SAP Inside Tracks are going to happen in the next two weeks. We highly recommend that you attend if you are looking to connect in person with other members in your area. To help you find these upcoming events more easily: SAP Inside Track Belgium, SAP Inside Track Warsaw, SAP Inside Track Philadelphia, SAP Inside Track Hamburg, SAP Inside Track Porto, SAP SIT RS (Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil).

entry.title: The International 2025 â€“ Review of TI14 with SAP & Team Liquid
entry.content:
The International 2025 â€“ Review of TI14 with SAP & Team Liquid

From September 11 to 14, 2025, the Barclays Arena in Hamburg became the center of the esports world. The International 2025 (TI14), the most important Dota 2 tournament of the year, brought together the 16 best teams. In addition to the legendary Aegis of Champions, a total prize pool of $2,694,437 was up for grabs â€“ funded by Valve's base pool plus community purchases in the Dota client.

Prize pool distribution (Top 4)

Team Falcons â€“ approx. $1,181,757 (43.9% of the pool)
ğŸ¥ˆXtreme Gaming â€“ approx. $305,163
ğŸ¥‰PARiVISION â€“ approx. $192,000
4ï¸âƒ£BetBoom Team â€“ approx. $128,000
The remaining teams received smaller prize money depending on their ranking.


Viewership & Reach

Peak Viewers: 1.77 million concurrent viewers in the Grand Final.
ğŸ“ŠAverage Viewers: approximately 835,000 over the entire event.
ğŸŒTI14 was broadcast in more than 20 languages worldwide.

This makes TI14 the third most popular Dota 2 event of all time, just behind TI10 and TI11.

Stadium at The International 2025Team LiquidStadiumPublic View on the Ongoing GamesPublic View on the Ongoing Games


SAP & Team Liquid â€“ Data in Esports

SAP has been working with Team Liquid since 2018, bringing business technology to gaming:

SAP HANA analytics helped Liquid evaluate over 500,000 draft scenarios and better understand opponents' strategies.
Liquid used statistical models to calculate hero pick probabilities â€“ similar to sales or demand forecasts in business.
Even though they didn't make it into the top 4 this year, Liquid was able to show several times during the tournament how data-driven strategies influence drafts and early-game decisions.


Tournament progress â€“ facts and figures

16 teams started in the group stage, which was played using the Swiss system.
A total of 51 matches were played, with an average game duration of 42 minutes.
Longest game: 77 minutes in the lower bracket, a real thriller that tested the nerves of both players and fans.
Most picked hero: Shadow Demon (48 picks, 56% win rate).
Highest KDA (kills/deaths/assists): A Falcons player with 14.2 in the Grand Final.


Significance & outlook

TI14 proved that esports and technology are increasingly converging.
For SAP, the partnership with Team Liquid is a showcase for data-driven innovation.
For fans, Hamburg was a worthy venue with a spine-tingling atmosphere.
TI15 will take place in Shanghai in 2026 â€“ a venue traditionally known for its vocal fans and gigantic arenas.

 

Conclusion

With over $2.6 million in prize money, nearly 2 million live viewers, and thrilling best-of-five series, TI14 was a worthy milestone in Dota 2 history.
Team Falcons will go down in history as the 2025 champions, while Team Liquid, with the help of SAP data analytics, proves that modern esports is not just about reaction time and instinct â€“ but also big data and smart strategy.

entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide to Creating a SOAP API in SAP S/4HANA and Configuring It Using SOAMANAGER
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,
In this blog post, I will walk you through the process of creating a SOAP-based web service in SAP S/4HANA, and demonstrate how to configure and expose it using SOAMANAGER for consumption by external systems.

What is SOAP API ?

SOAP API stands for Simple Object Access Protocol.

It is a protocol-based method of communication that allows different systems to exchange data over a network â€” usually using XML messages over HTTP or HTTPS.

Difference Between SOAP API and Rest API

Feature / Aspect          SOAP API (in SAP)                                    REST API (in SAP)

TechnologyWeb Service (Enterprise Service, Function Module via SOAMANAGER)OData service via SAP Gateway (or RAP in S/4HANA)
Tool UsedSPROXY,SOAMANAGER, SE37SAP Gateway, SEGW, CDS Views, RAP Model.
Data FormatXML onlyMostly JSON (also supports XML)
Typical Use CaseIntegration with legacy systems, middleware, PI/POFiori apps, mobile apps, third-party REST integrations
SecurityWS-Security, SAML, SSLHTTPS, OAuth 2.0, SAML
PerformanceHeavier (due to XML parsing and SOAP envelope)Faster and lighter (especially with JSON)
Contract DescriptionWSDL file.$metadata (EDMX format) via OData.
Preferred InECC or S/4 for BAPIs, ALE, PI/PO scenarios.S/4HANA, Fiori Elements, RESTful integrations.


Step 1:Create a Structure & Table Type for Request and Response.

Objects with the naming convention ZCH* are designed to be transported across all systems (DEV â†’ QA â†’ PROD).

In contrast, objects with the naming convention YCH* are typically created only for development purposes and are stored in the $TMP package, meaning they are local objects and will not be transported. These may be deleted later.

YCH_CUST_REQ is the request structure.



We need to save in $TMP.

YCH_CUST_REQ_TT is the table type which is consuming YCH_CUST_REQ structure

We are storing the request table type in $TMP

YCH_CUST_RES_S is the Response Payload and stored in the $tmp package




Table type YCH_CUST_RES_TT is the table type & it is consuming YCH_CUST_RES_S and stored in $TMP package.

 

Step2) Creating RFC FM and saved in $TMP Package

So here we are declaring IM_REQUEST as Import parameter with type of Table Type of Request (YCH_CUST_REQ_TT)


So here we are declaring EX_RESPONSE as Export parameter with type of Table Type of Request (YCH_CUST_RES_TT)

There will be no logic written inside the function module only Importing and exporting parameter will be defined

Step 3)Creation of Web service

We need to go for Utilities ->More Utilities->Create web service->From the function Module.

Provide the service definition name and Description

By Default it will take Function module name

By Default it will assign SOAP Appl & Profile


Click on local object check box so that by default it will be assigned to $TMP package

Click on finish to create web service

What is WSDL ?
It is an XML-based language used to describe web services and how to access them. Think of it as a contract between the service provider and the consumer, detailing what the service does, where it can be accessed, and how to interact with it.

Once after that go to WSDL tab and Click on export symbol and download the data in Notepad

So in the WSDL file change the filed type from "tns:char10" to "xsd: String" as below in the downloaded Notepad from WSDL tab.

 


Step 4) Go to Sproxy tcode

Click on New icon to create Service Consumer.

Select the service Consumer radio button


Select External/WSDL schema.

Chose local file

Choose the local file path for the WSDL.

Provide the package with workbench task request & provide the prefix so that we will taken as reference to create a SOAP class.

click on finish

Save the Service Consumer YSRV_SRV_DEF


Change the Release status from Not Released to Released state and Activate the Service Consumer.

So in the External View Tab we can see all Request and Response Fields.



Soap Class ZCH_CL_CO_YSRV_SRV_DEF will be generated automatically which is helpful in sending and receiving the data using the method YCUST_SOAP_API



Step 5) Execute SOAMANAGER Tcode.

An web page will be opened 

Select Web service Configuration

Search our proxy(YSRV_SRV_DEF) in Object type as showed below

We will get the SOAP Class click on that & go for Create -> Manual Configuration

Provide the Logical Port name & description. Click on next

So in Consumer Security Provide the User Id & Password that will be Provided from CPI team (Middleware/Integration Team).

Assign the Endpoint URL which will be Provided from CPI team (Middleware/Integration Team). which will be linked to CPI system.

Change the Message ID protocol to Suppress ID transfer and click on finish.

Once after finishing the soamanger configuration click on the below highlighted icon for Ping the web service.

By pinging the SOAMANGER web service we can Validate our Endpoint, Username & Password.

If it's Successful then we will get the result as below else we will get error.



Step 6)Create a report program that consumes a SOAP API to send and receive data.

REPORT zcv_r_soap_api.
DATA:ls_req TYPE zch_cl_soap_ycust_soap_api,   
     ls_res TYPE  zch_cl_soap_ycust_soap_apiresp.

SELECT FROM kna1 FIELDS kunnr,name1 INTO TABLE (gt_cust).

LOOP AT gt_cust INTO DATA(ls_cust).
  APPEND VALUE zch_cl_ych_cust_req( customer = ls_cust-kunnr name = ls_cust-name1 ) TO ls_req-im_request-item.
ENDLOOP.

DATA(go_ref)  = NEW zch_cl_co_ysrv_srv_def( ).
TRY.
    go_ref->ycust_soap_api(
      EXPORTING
        input  = ls_req
      IMPORTING
        output = ls_res
    ).
  CATCH cx_ai_system_fault INTO DATA(ls_error). " Communication Error
    MESSAGE ls_error->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
    ENDTRY.

In the  above report program, ZCH_CL_SOAP_YCUST_SOAP_API and ZCH_CL_SOAP_YCUST_SOAP_APIRESP are automatically generated structures from the proxy class ZCH_CL_CO_YSRV_SRV_DEF, and are defined as the exporting and importing parameters, respectively, for the method YCUST_SOAP_API.

In the report, I am using the statement APPEND VALUE ZCH_CL_YCH_CUST_REQ at line 8. Here, ZCH_CL_YCH_CUST_REQ is a deep structure that is part of the structure ZCH_CL_SOAP_YCUST_SOAP_API, which was generated by the proxy class.

Later, we created an object of the class ZCH_CL_CO_YSRV_SRV_DEF, through which we called the method YCUST_SOAP_API. The request data is passed in the structure ls_req, and the response is received in the structure ls_res.

Any errors related to the proxy call will be handled in the CATCH block using ABAP's TRY...CATCH exception handling mechanism.

entry.title: New Intelligent Search Available in Beta Phase
entry.content:
If you take a close look at the search field available throughout SAP Community, youâ€™ll notice a new option in the pulldown: Beta Search. This search introduces several new filtering options, including the ability to filter by SAP Managed Tag and by question status such as unanswered questions (one of the most requested features from members!). 

Powered by Coveo, this new federated search pulls from multiple repositories, not just SAP Community. In fact, this new search will also be available on other SAP sites â€“ including SAP.com, SAP Store, and SAP Support Portal â€“ with a consistent UI and design, creating a better user experience as visitors navigate across SAPâ€™s various online destinations. 

You can narrow your search down to specific sites from the top tabs â€“ selecting Products, Community, or Support â€“ but if you want hits from various platforms, you can refine via the All Results tab. From there, you can click several options under the Document Type dropdown. For example, in addition to the standard options that you would expect for SAP Community (such as Question, Discussion, and Blog Post), you can choose Learning Journey, SAP Knowledge Base Article, and News and Press. 

Thatâ€™s a small sample of whatâ€™s available. Looking for training content from SAP Developer Center? Click the Tutorial box. Need material from SAP Help Portal? Select Product Documentation. Thereâ€™s even a Video option if youâ€™re looking for media from SAP channels on YouTube.  

Additional options will allow you to find products directly on the SAP Store site. Depending on the search topic, you may even get an AI-generated answer â€“ although the beta results will require additional learning and refinement.  

While the results above may not be completely accurate, all of this search will get smarter over time â€“ thanks to you. Coveo relies on a machine-learning model that reacts to user behavior, so your activity will play an important role in improving search outcomes. 

And speaking of outcomes â€“ as an SAP Community member, youâ€™re likely interested in what the search outcomes mean for users trying to find information on our site. We encourage you to test the beta search and see for yourself. Youâ€™ll notice some options remain the same, compared to the platformâ€™s current search â€“ such as filtering by date â€“ whereas options for searching for users and authors are gone - but will come back with later phases of the search project.

Youâ€™ll also find a few new dropdowns, including menus for filtering SAP Community results by specific products and SAP Managed Tags. You can select multiple options from recommendations or search available products and tags to fine-tune results. 

Perhaps most importantly, youâ€™ll be able to filter questions by status (answered, solved, and open), meeting one of the biggest demands from members looking to find (or provide) solutions to problems. 

During the beta phase, youâ€™ll still be able to use the normal SAP Community site search. Results for the beta search will only pull public content â€“ meaning you wonâ€™t be able to use it to find information from any private groups (if you belong to any).  

We expect the beta phase to run through the rest of 2025 â€“ possibly into the middle of 2026. Weâ€™ll provide updates about future phases in Whatâ€™s New as they become available. 

Try the new beta search for yourself, compare it to the current search, and leave your questions and observations in the comments below or give feedback via our community inbox community@sap.com. We look forward to your feedback!

entry.title: Update to our Rules of Engagement
entry.content:
We have updated our Rules of Engagement today.

To explain in short what has changed since the last version: 

  • Article 1 now describes the participation etiquette that we expect all community members to follow, as well as outlines the general rules for content publication. For more in-depth information on the participation etiquette and tips for participation in the community, please read this article in our Welcome Corner group. 
  • Article 2 contains information on user profile information. 
  • Article 3 describes content which constitutes "Unacceptable Content". Content that is listed in article 3 may either by rejected or removed. The categories here are now aligned with changes the EU made to the Digital Services Act (DSA) categories this year. All abuse reports under article 3 will be subject to DSA.
  • The old article 3 has been removed, which means publishing content about job opportunities and job postings are no longer permitted in the SAP Community.
  • Article 4 has not changed and remains the same. 

With these updates to our rules of engagement, we continue to ensure the best possible content quality and community experience for our members..

entry.title: Thanks for attending SAP Tech Night at SAP Labs Gurgaon â€“ A Night of Ideas, Inspiration & Community
entry.content:
SAP Tech Night at SAP Labs Gurgaon â€“ A Night of Ideas, Inspiration & Community ğŸŒ™ğŸ’¡

Yesterday, we had the privilege of hosting  SAP Community Tech Night at SAP Labs Gurgaon, and what an incredible evening it turned out to be! 

The Flow of the Evening ğŸŒŸ

âœ¨ A Warm Beginning

The evening began with my welcome to everyone and a brief sharing of the agenda, followed by Jitan Batra and Neeraj Manocha, who painted a vivid picture of the SAP Community journeyâ€”from Stammtisch and Tech Nights to Inside Tracks. Their words reminded us that behind every great community lies the spirit of people coming together, sharing, and growing.

âš¡ The Future with SAP Joule
I had the opportunity to present SAP Jouleâ€”exploring its role for developers, consultants, studios, skills, automation, and agents. What struck me most wasnâ€™t just delivering the sessionâ€”it was the spark in the room, the curiosity, and the conversations that followed. The future of work with Joule feels closer than ever.

ğŸ¤– AI Transforming Support
Nirjar Gandhi then took us on a journey into AI-driven customer support, showcasing tools like Early Watch, Application Conversion Assistant, App Inspector in S/4HANA 2025, and Intelligent Log Analysis. It was one of those sessions that made us realizeâ€”AI isnâ€™t a buzzword here, itâ€™s solving real problems today.

ğŸŒ Rise with SAP
Closing the formal sessions, Niharika Razdan spoke about Rise with SAP and how itâ€™s reshaping ERP. Her perspective on the role of SAP Basis consultants sparked important discussions about career growth, transformation, and the opportunities ahead.

ğŸ¤ Networking & Next Steps
The networking session was buzzingâ€”people exchanging ideas, making plans, and brainstorming about the upcoming SAP Inside Track Gurgaon on 15-Nov-2025. It was community in action, and it felt powerful.

ğŸ´ Dinner Together
Finally, over dinner, conversations flowed as naturally as the food. Because at the heart of every great community event is not just learning together, but also sharing a meal and building friendships.

Gratitude ğŸ™

  • To the speakers for making the sessions insightful and inspiring.

  • To the attendees from across SAP, IBM, TCS, Accenture, Capgemini, The Silicon Partner, and more â€“ for bringing your passion and energy.

  • To SAP Labs Gurgaon â€“ for hosting us so warmly.

  • To everyone who supported and organized behind the scenes â€“ you made it all possible.

Whatâ€™s Next? ğŸš€

The excitement doesnâ€™t end here. With discussions already underway for the SAP Inside Track Gurgaon, weâ€™re just getting started.

Last night reminded me of this truth: Technology changes fast, but itâ€™s the people, the community, and the shared learning that make the biggest difference. And thatâ€™s what SAP Community is all about.

ğŸ‘‰ Were you part of SAP Tech Night? Share your favorite highlight or takeaway in the commentsâ€”Iâ€™d love to hear your perspective!

On behalf of SAP Community NCR
